org.firewaterframework.rest
Class Request

java.lang.Object
  org.firewaterframework.rest.Request

public class Request
extends java.lang.Object

This class is the Request object for the Firewater framework. It contains the request URL, any arguments, and the METHOD of the underlying request.

Constructor Detail

Request

public Request(java.lang.String url,
               Method method,
               org.springframework.beans.MutablePropertyValues args,
               boolean argsAlreadyProcessed)
Create a new REST request. Note that incoming URLs are not complete URLs, but rather logical URLs stripped of protocol, host, port, application, and prefix. For example, if our actual Firewater servlet for handling web request is rooted at http://www.abc.com/myapp/webservices/ and our web API is configured to handle the /pets resource request. Then the url attribute in this Request object will simply be /pets.

Parameters:
url - the URL of the Requested resource
method - GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, HEAD or OPTIONS
args - the arguments
argsAlreadyProcessed - this is true for those callers that have already URLdecoded the query string into the args (ie. Servlets). If you want the Request object to decode and parse the query string, set this to false (default behaviour of the other constructors).

getBaseUrl

setInternalUrl

public void setInternalUrl(java.lang.String url)
Setting the internal url of this request implies that any arguments passed in with the URL (eg /pets?age=9®ion=4) will be parsed out and added to the args of this request. Note that the Request will differentiate between the id URL and the baseURL. The baseURL is the URL stripped of any arguments and is the URL to actually match against the configured list of patterns. Note that downstream cacheing schemes must use the full url in order accurately cache appropriate Responses for the given Request.

Servlet containers will have already parsed the query string and added those values to the args. This method will typically only be used by the constructors that don't include the query string, which will be called from non-servlet front ends (like APIs or testcases).

Parameters:
url - the full logical url, including arguments for this request
See Also:
RouteMapper
